This is useful for creating avatars or for testing purposes. Installation ------------ Install with pip:: pip install django-robohash-svg Then declare the app in your settings.py :: INSTALLED_APPS = [ ... 'django_robohash', ] Usage ----- If you want an inline image in your template use the robohash tag :: {% load robohash %} ... here is a robot: {% robohash "a string" %} a small one : {% robohash "a string" width=100 height=100 %} If you want to serve robot images, edit your urls.py and use robohash view :: from django_robohash.views import robohash urlpatterns = [ ... path('robohash//', robohash, name='robohash') ] You can custom the url if you want, but keep "". Then you can display image like this :: or Default robots size is 300x300 You can generate the svg code by running this function:: from django_robohash.robotmaker import make_robot_svg ... svg_code = make_robot_svg("my string", width=300, height=300) News ==== 0.9.4 (2018-08-13) ------------------ - Add documentation 0.0.1 (2018-03-22) ------------------ - Skeleton commit
info.name: django-robohash-svg
info.html_description:
Django app for creating svg robots

The idea: from any string (username, first name and last name, etc…), obtain a unique svg robot to display. This is useful for creating avatars or for testing purposes.

Installation

Install with pip:

pip install django-robohash-svg

Then declare the app in your settings.py

INSTALLED_APPS = [
...
    'django_robohash',
]

Usage

If you want an inline image in your template use the robohash tag

{% load robohash %}
...
here is a robot:
{% robohash "a string" %}
a small one :
{% robohash "a string" width=100 height=100 %}

If you want to serve robot images, edit your urls.py and use robohash view

from django_robohash.views import robohash

urlpatterns = [
    ...
    path('robohash/<string>/', robohash,
         name='robohash')
]

You can custom the url if you want, but keep “<string>”.

Then you can display image like this

<img src="/robohash/{{ a_string }}/">

or

<img src="/robohash/{{ a_string }}/?width=120&height=120">

Default robots size is 300x300

You can generate the svg code by running this function:

from django_robohash.robotmaker import make_robot_svg
...
svg_code = make_robot_svg("my string", width=300, height=300)

News

0.9.4 (2018-08-13)

  • Add documentation

0.0.1 (2018-03-22)

  • Skeleton commit
